item.title: Warhammer Quest Darkwater Review - Can't Stop The Rot
item.content:encoded:
A rot that started long ago in the Jade Abbey has surged, making a final push, seeking to taint the sacred water of the Everspring. One of its former keepers has gathered a group to stop this from happening, hoping to save the entire realm from falling entirely to the Chaos god Nurgle. Warhammer Quest is back! In this spoiler-free article, we check out the brand new set, Warhammer Quest Darkwater.

We've covered previous editions of Warhammer Quest on the site, including the futuristic Warhammer 40,000 iteration, Warhammer Quest Blackstone Fortress, and the horror-filled streets of Warhammer Quest Cursed City.

What's the Quest?

The original Warhammer Quest hit tabletops in 1995, following the earlier success of HeroQuest, which has also seen a recent revival. Games Workshop brought Warhammer Quest back in 2016, and since then, we've seen new iterations, using the same concept of players cooperatively exploring and conquering a dungeon. Each edition has had variations in rules and mechanics, along with a brand-new setting for each.

This time, Warhammer Quest continues to explore the depths of the Age of Sigmar setting, moving away from the snowy, cramped, and death-filled streets of Ulfenkarn to Ghyran, the realm of life, and the Jade Abbey, the source of the powerful waters of the Everspring, for which Nurlge, the plague god, has set his sights.

I absolutely love the background for Warhammer Quest Darkwater. Gelgus Pust, a Chaos Champion of Nurgle, has sought to control the Everspring ever since he betrayed his order. Once a senior in the Jade Abbey, his lust for power corrupted him, and he brought others with him in a revolt that nearly captured the Everspring. To stop him, the Everqueen flooded the Jade Abbey, wiping out attackers and defenders alike, but keeping the Everspring from falling into the Chaos God's hands.

Pust has since been on a ruthless campaign, steadily weakening the defences of the Jade Abbey over centuries until he's now in a position to strike. But there are heroes willing to risk it all to stop him. Gathered by Inara Sion, a former colleague of Gelgus and the last surviving member of the Jade Circle, tasked with defending the Everspring. The battle between Pust and Inara, finally coming to settle the score after centuries, sets the stage for the adventure.

Mechanics Of Life

Warhammer Quest Darkwater has several mechanical changes from previous editions. The first is the inclusion of a map book, which takes the place of the map tiles from previous editions. This takes away the ability to randomly generate maps and instead fixes maps to those available in the map book. There is still variety to be found, and different missions, enemies, and map placement can make the same map into an entirely new experience. The benefit of the map book is that it speeds up setup time to almost nothing, as you only have to find the map page of the quest card, set up the enemies, heroes, and items, and you're ready to play. In a game that can serve as an entry game into the wider Warhammer and Age of Sigmar settings, this change is very welcome and lets you focus on the core delivery, rather than spending time building a map out of tiles.

The second noticeable mechanical change is that actions are now cards. Each hero starts with 3 core action cards, move, attack, and aid, and each has the dual effect of letting you complete the action and providing the energy to complete other actions. Each time you use an action card, you need to expend other action cards with enough energy to complete the action, which can include the action you are completing.

So you can exhaust the aid card to move, then exhaust the move card to move, and then the attack card to attack, or use all 3 to attack, or any combination thereof. Characters can also gain other action cards, increasing their available energy for the turn, and actions not on cards can also be taken with special quest actions, or individual character actions detailed on their character card. This mechanic will be familiar to those who've played Warhammer Quest The Adventure Card Game, and was one of my favorite mechanics from the game.

I've always loved the action card mechanic, it makes it super clear what you can do each turn and keeps everything really clean visually, especially as you gain actions that provide energy. It really feels like leveling up your hero as they can complete more each turn. The action mechanics themselves are also really straightforward, with the number of dice to roll in an attack listed, and the number you need to roll as well. Enemies block attacks equal to their defence value, which keeps combat really quick.

Most of the starting characters have a random value for movement, which I was initially skeptical of, but was on board with immediately when playing. It takes away from the fixed puzzle nature of some games, where you know if you move here, you can attack or take this action. The randomness of possibly having to take 2 move actions to get to where you need to be, or having a great dice roll and getting there in 1 move, feels very heroic. It also feels very in keeping with regular board games, where your movement is usually based on a dice roll. The exception to this is Drolf, the Duardin, who has a fixed move. This feels very thematic and sets Drolf out with the fixed, determined nature of the Duardin, but also their restriction on speed.

Enemies are controlled with custom dice that give them a simple series of actions they carry out when activated, with stronger enemies taking multiple actions as they scale up. Their movement and attacks feel purposeful, but are quick and simple enough that you get to focus on the heroes, rather than getting bogged down in the minutia of individual swarms of enemies.

Heroes Of The Tale

Warhammer Quest Darkwater features 4 heroes initially, and 3 unlockable heroes that you'll see on the box of the game, and as you put the miniatures together for the set. We'll leave you to discover the 3 unlockable heroes, but the 4 core heroes are:

  • Edmark Valoran, known as the Manticore Knight, has the best defense of the heroes and has a chance to damage adjacent enemies when he blocks their hits. He starts the game with the Shield of the Manticore, which can be used to automatically block a hit before a saving throw.
  • Bren Tylis, the Renegade Saint, gets to choose each round to reroll her move, attack, or save rolls. It's a pretty powerful ability, giving you a better chance to achieve what you need to that round. Bren starts the game with the Relics of the Past equipment card, which can be used when you discard a reward card to stop it from being discarded on a 5+, which is great for keeping some single-use items around.
  • Inara Sion, the Cleansing Blade, has a poor defence, but a great ranged attack to keep her away from enemies. They also have a Barrier of Water ability on their card, which can be used like the core abilities to block hexes to enemies, and make lethal hexes safe for the heroes. Their Blade of Flowing Water equipment also lets her move the counter for free, without having to power the ability.
  • Drolf Ironhead, the Grizzled Explorer, has a fixed movement, a ranged attack, and can ignore lethal hexes by sprinting through them (by spending more energy on the move card to move 6 hexes instead of the standard movement). They come equipped with the Ranger's Kit, which can let them move through blocked hexes, which is amazing for last-minute objective saves or flanking an enemy who might have your party pinned.

Standing Against The Rot

The Warhammer Quest Darkwater campaign consists of 3 acts, and each act is made up of 15 act cards (drawn randomly from 32 for each act). Each act has a final boss (of which there are 3 possible scenarios to face them in), and another 14 cards made up of encounters, events, and rest sites.

This means that you could play the game through all 3 acts, deliberately using different cards for each play-through, and have 2 unique play-throughs with still a spare card and an extra boss scenario, but the randomisation element will keep each play-through unique, or if you just want a one-off game, you can use any of the acts in skirmish mode.

Playing through the campaign first, before embarking on skirmish mode, is worthwhile, as you unlock extra characters and rewards as you do, and it avoids spoilers in skirmish mode, should you wish to play through the entire campaign.

Each encounter is pretty fast to play through, and you can get through a few in an evening, or half an act if you're lucky with event and rest site cards. This is helped by the quick setup for each encounter, letting you progress onto the next quickly. There are also several storage boxes for the heroes and acts, to keep the cards tidy in the box, and help you remember where you got to if you do have to pack away before finishing the campaign.

Warhammer Quest Darkwater Final Thoughts?

I had an absolute blast with Warhammer Quest Darkwater. I started my journey into miniatures gaming with Heroquest in the early '90s, and I played the original Warhammer Quest on release a few years later, so there's always been a bit of nostalgia here for me. Having also played the last 2 iterations, Blackstone Fortress and Cursed City, and reviewing them here on the site, this has been one of my favourite dungeon crawler games to date. The setting is perfect, and it captures the oppressive rot nature of Nurgle, whilst still being accessible for gamers who might be having their first experience here. 

Set up is fast, and games have a great flow with straightforward AI control for the enemies. The heroes feel unique, and the campaign is fast-flowing, but long enough to give it a great sense of depth. Repeat plays are also possible with the number of act cards across the 3 acts, and randomising them when generating the campaign. Previous Warhammer Quest editions got multiple expansions, and I hope that we see that here for Darkwater too.

The copy of Warhammer Quest Darkwater used to produce this review was provided by Games Workshop.

item.title: Best Gifts for Streamers & Content Creators 2025
item.content:encoded:
The competitive nature of streaming and content creation in the modern day means having the right equipment and set-up is invaluable, which means that gifts for streamers and content creators in 2025 can make a big difference.

Insider Gaming has collated the list below to showcase some of the top picks for gifts for anyone you know who is a streamer or content creator this holiday season, covering all budgets.

Don’t forget to check out Insider Gaming’s other holiday 2025 guides for more gift ideas and some of the best deals around.

Best 2025 Gifts for Streamers & Content Creators

Elgato Stream Deck Mk. 2

The Stream Deck is a must-have item for any streamer, and while other products might offer the same service, it’s the best in the market. With programmable buttons that make it easier to switch between scenes, trigger on-screen effects, and more, it’s one of the best gifts for streamers.

Custom Gamer Tag Neon Sign

Anyone looking to jazz up their streaming set up should definitely take a look at the Custom Gamer Tag Neon Sign, which lights up the room and simultaneously acts as promotion for their brand. It’s the perfect background for a streamer, as it easily promotes their account in any clips that are cut.

The Ultimate Streamer’s Log Book

Keeping ideas fresh is a tough challenge for any streamer or content creator, and finding the right approach can be tricky. That’s where The Ultimate Streamer’s Log Book comes in handy, providing over 100 stream challenges to help you stay organized and come up with fresh approaches.

KDD Headset Stand With Charging Station

Any streamer or content creator needs to ensure they have all their required equipment fully charged and ready to go, which is where the KDD Headset Stand comes in perfectly. Equipped with 2 USB and 1 type-C charging port, it can be used to charge smartphones, tablets, headphones, controllers, and more, making it among the best gifts for streamers.

Overhead Camera Mount with Ring Light

If you’re thinking of doing top-down content, like pack openings or drawings, an overhead camera with a light is a must-have, and this has both in one. Compatible with iPhone and Logitech webcams, among others, this camera mount attaches to the desk and provides everything you need for a quick set-up.

PQRQP 3-in-1 Wireless Lavalier Microphone

Recording content on the go means you should have a clippable microphone to block out background noise and focus on exactly the source you want, and this 3-in-1 microphone presents an affordable option. Compatible with iPhone, Android, cameras, and more, it’s the perfect tool for content creating on the go.

Frigidaire Retro 9-Can Personal Fridge

Long sessions on stream or editing content can be taxing, and you don’t want to have to keep on going in and out for refreshments. A mini fridge on hand is therefore advised, and the Frigidaire Retro 9-Can Personal Fridge has enough room to keep you going in a long stint, and a nice design to boot.

Elgato Prompter

Keeping engaged with chat is crucial for any live streamer or content creator, but you don’t want to crank your neck turning your head to different monitors. The Elgato prompter counters that, showing a live feed of chat to interact with, or, if recording content, showing a script to follow.

Neewer Collapsible Backdrop

A green screen might not be an immediate necessity but, once you start using it, you’ll never look the other way again. The Neewer Collapsible Backdrop has both green and blue screen, coming double-sided, and is easy to put up and store, all available for a decent price.

Elgato 4K S External Capture Card

A capture card is one of the most important items for any streamer or content creators, as it quickly captures all content from an external source, like a console, and connects it to PC and your stream. Without it, you’ll be limited on your options when streaming, and it should be one of the first things you pick up when you get started.

item.title: Best Family-Friendly Games 2025: Holiday Guide
item.content:encoded:
The holiday season is the perfect time to gather around a console with loved ones to tackle multiplayer titles, both co-operatively and competitively, and there are some great family-friendly titles on the market in 2025.

From famous franchises to titles that may have gone under your radar, there’s a wide array of family-friendly games to try out this holiday season, and Insider Gaming has gathered some of the best options across multiple platforms.

Don’t forget to check out Insider Gaming’s other holiday 2025 guides for game suggestions and some of the best deals available!

Best Family-Friendly Games 2025

Super Mario Party Jamboree

The Super Mario Party franchise has been among the greatest games to play with family over the years, and it’s no different with the latest entry, Jamboree. Available on Nintendo Switch platforms, Jamboree is packed with over 110 minigames, more than any other title in the franchise’s history.

Overcooked! All You Can Eat

If you still haven’t played the Overcooked! games in 2025, you’re really missing out. Thankfully, the All You Can Eat edition is the perfect solution, as it includes both the original game and the sequel, along with all additional content. The variety of levels will put your teamwork to the test, and it won’t take long for you to find a favorite among the loveable characters.

Moving Out

A game with a similar vibe to Overcooked! Moving Out is a co-operative game based around helping people pack up their belongings and move house, but there are always some tricks in store. Some objects require careful movement, others are easy to break, and every level has hidden objectives to discover for bonus rewards.

PowerWash Simulator 2

Don’t knock it until you’ve tried it. PowerWash Simulator 2 is the perfect calm to wind down during the frantic holiday season, offering an array of levels to test your cleaning abilities with, more tools for the job than you will ever need, and extreme satisfication when you complete every level.

LEGO Party!

The new market competitor to Super Mario Party, LEGO Party! offers similar gameplay experiences, but in brick form. The 4-player party game is available on most platforms, a huge advantage with Super Mario Party being Nintendo exclusive, and offers 60 minigames to compete against each other in the wacky Challenge Zones.

Mario Kart World

A Nintendo Switch 2 exclusive, Mario Kart World is the long-awaited latest entry in the Mario Kart franchise, and is stacked full of tracks to compete on, and a vast open world to explore. As you’d expect, the title is filled with all your favorite characters from the Mario franchise, and there are plenty of costumes and variants to discover along the way.

Minecraft

Minecraft continues to be one of the best family-friendly games available on the market, providing an entire sandbox to play in. Whether you want to explore or build, or beat the game by defeating the Ender Dragon, Minecraft has endless hours of entertainment, and is one of the best multiplayer games you can get.

Astro Bot

The 2024 platform game from Team Asobi is a PlayStation 5 exclusive and stands as one of the best games available on the platform. With over 50 planets to complete, each filled with a tough course to navigate and boss battles, there’s plenty to tick off, and the game is a who’s who in PlayStation history with bot versions of a host of famous characters from a variety of franchise.

Disney Dreamlight Valley

Disney Dreamlight Valley is effectively Animal Crossing with Disney characters, putting players in charge of building a village filled with fan-favorite characters from Disney and Pixar titles, including the big names from Frozen, Moana, Toy Story, the Lion King, and more. With a host of mini-quests to complete, and plenty to collect, Dreamlight Valley is a game that sucks you in quickly.

Ultimate Chicken Horse

Those looking for a different sort of competitive title this holiday season should take a look at Ultimate Chicken Horse, a platform game with a difference. Each round, every player selects an item to add to the course that can make completing it easier or more difficult. It brings out a different sort of competitive edge, and an endless gameplay loop.

item.title: EDEN.schemata(); delayed to 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PC

No longer due out this winter.

Publisher PLAYISM will developers illuCalab. and WSS playground-have delayed science-fiction mystery adventure game EDEN.schemata(); from its previously planned winter release window to 2026. It will be available for PC via Steam with English, Japanese, and Simplified Chinese language support.

Here is the full message from the developers on the delay:

We had originally planned to release EDEN.schemata(); this winter.

However, in order to further refine one of the game’s cores “narrative and gameplay flow that changes based on the player’s actions,” we have decided to adjust the release window to a planned launch of 2026.

We sincerely apologize to everyone who has been looking forward to the game.

The development team is working with the utmost dedication to deliver an even better experience.

A Letter from the Developers

To everyone who has been waiting for this game, we are truly sorry.

The release date has been moved to “2026.” We apologize for keeping you waiting yet again. The support we’ve received, from the excitement voiced across various communities to the feedback from players who tried the demo at events, has been a tremendous source of encouragement for our team. We are deeply grateful.

This project involves implementing an unusual system into the game. We believe this system will make the experience truly one-of-a-kind, but such an ambitious approach also presents significant challenges.

There were moments when we wondered if perhaps creating a game like this was too early for us—or even for humanity—but after much trial and error, the final vision is gradually taking shape. Because we want to present the game at its best, we kindly ask for a little more time.

Additionally, because of how the game plays, the user interface, and story all change based on the player’s actions. Which means even sharing small bits of information becomes potential spoilers. This has made it difficult to communicate ongoing progress through social media, even though development is continuing steadily each day under director EIKI.

We are eagerly looking forward to the day when we can share this game with all of you, and we hope you will look forward to it as well. Your patience would mean the world to us.

Thank you once again for your continued support of EDEN.schemata();.

item.title: Occult horror visual novel Resequence: The Orchard announced for PC
item.content:encoded:
CLEAR RAVE has announced Resequence: The Orchard, an occult horror visual novel coming to PC via Steam in 2026. It will support English, Japanese, and Simplified Chinese language options, with other languages to possibly be added later.

Here is an overview of the game, via its Steam page:

About

An occult horror adventure lurking beyond the case file.

Resequence: The Orchard is a multi-perspective occult-horror adventure game about an otherworldly presence slowly eroding everyday life, featuring unsettling visuals by fracoco and a story by Re,AER.

Players would play the role of Kisuke Saito and uncover the students’ past by hearing their experiences. Reveal the truth of his wife’s missing and eventually bring out what lies beneath the record—what’s haunted “there.”

Story

Feeling extremely hard to move on after his wife’s missing and drained of the will to live, Kisuke Saito—encouraged by his colleague Aislinn and a high school girl Kaneko Honda—accepted the job as a school counselor. But every student who comes to him is plagued by inexplicable phenomena…

Key Features

  • A visual novel focused on the story.
  • The story continues through mouse clicks and dialogue choices.
  • More than five characters and each with standing portraits.
  • Different stories based on your selections.

Yunyun Syndrome!? Rhythm Psychosis is a rhythm adventure game about a psychotic hikikomori girl—also an avid anonymous poster—who corrupts the world with her severe brain rot from listening to too many denpa songs. Yunyun all over this ♡♡♡♡ world with your degen otaku-posting.

High and vibin’ with denpa songs, we’ll corrupt the entire Internet! Hehe. all we need is a bit of otaku love, that’s all.

item.title: Into the Fire launches in Early Access in 2026
item.content:encoded:
Anti-combat action adventure RPG Into the Fire will launch in Early Access for PC via Steam and GOG in 2026, developer Starward Industries announced. A playtest is coming “soon.”

Here is an overview of the game, via Starward Industries:

About

Combining action, survival, and arcade elements, Into the Fire will have you braving the fury of nature as you face volcanic demons on Dante’s Archipelago. Armed with fantastic retro inventions and firefighting weapons, you will need to combat a deadly disaster and extract as many lives as possible in a time-pressing run for survival. Discover fiery myths, unexplained phenomena, and mysterious relics lurking within the inferno. Challenge the world of fire and ash—upgrade your gear, expand your base, and take part in dark rituals as you fight against the volcano’s wrath. Once its breath reaches you, every second counts.

Gameplay Features

  • High-Stakes Rescue Gameplay – Feel the rush of being a first responder in an unfolding catastrophe, where every second counts and every choice has consequences.
  • Innovative Firefighting Arsenal – Wield unique tools like a suppression pistol, extinguishing shotgun, and fire bomb launcher to battle flames and carve paths to safety.
  • Dynamic Disaster Environment – Face an ever-changing volcanic landscape where collapsing terrain, ash storms, and unpredictable eruptions force constant adaptation.
  • The Hub: A Living Base – More than just a shelter, the Hub is your strategic nerve center—plan rescues, gather intel, upgrade your arsenal, and uncover the island’s darkest secrets.
  • Traversal and Mobility Focus – Use rope systems, retro sleds, and other tools to navigate treacherous terrain and reach those in need before time runs out.
  • Survival Through Strategy – Read seismographs, manage resources, and make tactical decisions to stay one step ahead of both natural and supernatural threats.
  • Fantastical Retro-Inspired Gadgets – Inspired by pioneering volcanologists, use experimental gear like fireproof shields and acid-resistant boats to survive the inferno.
  • Mystery and Myth Collide – As you fight to save lives, uncover an ancient force beyond science and face the eerie adversaries lurking within the chaos.
  • Time as a Resource – Disaster is relentless—prioritize, act fast, and make sacrifices to ensure the survival of as many as possible.
  • Inspired by Ryszard Kapuscinski’s famous books.

item.title: Reminder: Metroid Prime 4: Beyond Is Available With A Switch Game Voucher
item.content:encoded:
You can also pay to upgrade to the Switch 2 version

Metroid Prime 4: Beyond is just days out from launch, and in case you missed it, you can redeem the eShop version of this title with a Nintendo Switch Game Voucher. You could also grab this version with a voucher and then pay to upgrade to the Switch 2 Edition of the game.

This follows the news in July that Nintendo would be discontinuing Switch Online Vouchers. Although these vouchers will no longer be sold after 30th January 2026, Nintendo has said it will continue to add Switch titles to the voucher catalogue throughout the same year. Vouchers will remain valid for 12 months from the purchase date.

One of the other titles to recently join the Switch voucher program was Pokémon Legends: Z-A, which you can also pay to upgrade to the Switch 2 version. Nintendo hasn't announced if it will release a similar voucher program for the Switch 2 (at least for now), but if we hear anything, we'll let you know.

Will you be using a voucher to redeem Metroid Prime 4: Beyond on the Switch? Are you planning on upgrading to the Switch 2 version? Let us know in the comments.

item.title: Flotsam launches December 5
item.content:encoded:
• PC

Floating city builder leaving Early Access after six years.

Floating city builder Flotsam will leave Early Access and launch for PC via Steam and GOG on December 5, Stray Fawn Publishing and developer Pajama Llama Games announced.

Flotsam first launched in Early Access on September 26, 2019.

Here is an overview of the game, via its Steam page:

About

Sail, scavenge, and rescue survivors in a vibrant floating city-builder. Captain your drifters across the endless garbage sea to uncover soaked ruins, rusting factories, and stories from the old world.

Build Your Floating Home

Turn ocean garbage into homes, workshops and colorful little gardens.

  • Collect floating plastic and driftwood, salvage scraps of the old world, and recycle them into homes that stay afloat.
  • Desalinate water, gut fish and board up a shelter to keep everyone safe.
  • Decorate your town with plants, refurbished furniture and statues that keep your drifters happy.

Travel the Sea With Your Town

Set sail to explore the flooded world, from soaked ruins to forgotten islands, and discover what still floats beyond the horizon.

  • Explore flooded remnants of the old world.
  • Rescue stranded survivors and friendly animals.
  • Re-discover old technology to improve your town. But be careful your drifters don’t get sick. The old world is polluted!

Meet Unique Drifters and Specialists

Your drifters each have their own stories to tell. Recruit specialists who unlock new buildings, quests, and discoveries for your floating community.

  • Find unique drifters like the Birdkeeper, Chemist, and Electrician.
  • Unlock new technologies and story quests through their expertise.

item.title: Story-driven adventure game All Adrift announced for PC
item.content:encoded:
About

Face the history laid upon the operating table, and the countenance of humanity.

Drift atop the records of sin humanity has left behind, and answer for the meaning of existence and salvation.

Whether in darkness or in light, walk upon the edge of humankind’s end, and bare your most human self.

All Adrift is an aesthetic epic on a cosmic scale—a fusion of literary text, painterly visuals, and the interplay of classical and modern music.

The player becomes Sian Lightchaser—a survivor of an immortal, cursed race, captured by the Arwin Empire and forced to perform surgery on the history of the universe.

She is imprisoned in the role of a Sacred Author, tasked with creating a religion to glorify Arwin’s eternal authority and the deification of its ruling class.
Sian drifts through a cosmos where the ending war has dragged on for four centuries beyond the armistice, repainting the history of the universe as both victim and collaborator.

This work is a narrative-driven simulation adventure that explores the irony of guilt and survival through Sian—dispatched across multiple universes to create “Arwinism” for those who massacred her own people, and compelled to confront the unfathomable vastness and histories of the cosmos as she operates on the past and present of planets.

It is not merely a “game to be played,” but a “philosophical opera” that asks how humanity survives within the indelible memory of its own sins.

…

Sian sits in the carriage, gazing out the window. A beautiful flash of gold spreads like a fracture, cracking through the white clouds, as if to swallow the entire sky, then fades. Arwin Type 38; perhaps the light shed by that terminal technology as it swept across yet another helpless galaxy. She envisions the histories erased by that fleeting light. Are those the scars of human sin, or the creases of a world fading away? Either could be true. In an age where humane reflection itself has turned into an odd taste, she plays, if only briefly, the role of an oddity.

Sian still sits in the carriage, gazing out the window. Among the guides busily selling death, one rushes toward the carriage with the vigor of a market peddler, reminding her that this planet she has just arrived on is experimenting with the entertainment of death.

The Most Ecstatic Deaths: Best Selection

That ironic title is brazenly stitched in bright thread across the cover the guide thrusts at her window—beside an illustration of the dead, smiling faintly as they lie in ordered rows. The headless coachman gestured threateningly for him to leave. The guide’s eyes, having found no head to glare at, briefly wandered the coachman’s body—until they caught the emblem of Arwin. The moment they did, his eyes dropped, as if to escape a gaze that does not exist.

In front of all this fuss, Sian sits in the carriage, gazing out the window. Her focus drifts indifferently to the billboard above the road.

Casualties Today: 91,060,000,080

Four hundred years of ceasefire, held in the name of peace negotiations—and despite centuries of propaganda declaring that “the war is ending,” countless lives still vanish each day, leaving nothing behind, consumed as numbers wielded by those who are unaccountable. Just a numbers game. An endless numbers game. A goddamn huge numbers game. As Sian stares at the board, trying to count the numbers that must have vanished during the long truce, when a sudden voice bursts from the carriage speaker, the fervent cry of the propaganda hour.

“History is written in Arwin’s handwriting!”

Lies.

“Our noble honor is born from devotion to the Empire…”

Noble lies.

“The great Arwinian does not fear death—death fears the Arwinian!”

Great, filthy lies.

“Entrust your future to the Empire!”

That one’s honest.

In this world that can reach every star, whose freedom stretches long only to narrow into a cage, Sian listens to the propaganda echoing through the carriage and thinks.

Is even this not enough? After obliterating all those peoples, after wiping out all those planets, after rendering all those lives less than mere numbers, is there still something left that must be carved away, resurrecting even this forbidden technology of cosmic surgery?

She looks at the cursed surgical instrument in her hand, the tool that can turn every life beyond the window into something less than a number. The weight of karma crushes her, suffocating every thought and feeling. Tomorrow’s throat lies in her hand. And now, it is her turn to wield it.

Surely, there is no god in such a cruel world. Certainly not. Even if there were, it would not be one from which we could hope for salvation. But that was the story up to now. What of tomorrow? At the heart of Arwin’s capital, a tower white enough to be black coils like a serpent, coveting the seat of a godless world as it creeps darkly toward tomorrow.

Above all these stories, Sian sits imprisoned in the carriage. For a while yet, she will remain so.

Ribbit!

  • Game Designer, Programmer: Woo Gi Hun
  • Composer: Park Na Hyun
  • Voice Cast: Mare Flos, Bae Sang Hyun, Kim Han Baek
  • Trailer Voice: Kim Sin Woo

item.title: Talking Point: What Are You Playing This Weekend? (29th November)
item.content:encoded:
The end of November is finally upon us (how??), so let's distract ourselves from the topic of ever-marching time by seeing what everyone's gaming plans are this weekend.

It was a somewhat quieter week in Nintendo Land this time, but there were still a few nice stories to keep us entertained. Nintendo picked up Bandai Namco Studios Singapore as a subsidiary, we got a brand-new content update for Hyrule Warriors: Age of Imprisonment, four new titles arrived on the Nintendo Switch Online NES and Game Boy libraries, and the Switch 2 landed a new system update.

We also shared our full reviews of Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition, Glory Hunters, Plants vs. Zombies: Replanted and Morsels.

But now it's the weekend, so what's everyone up to?

Jim Norman, Staff Writer

This is my final weekend before all the games release, so I'm determined to wrap up Clair Obscur and get a run or two of Absolum under my belt. Yes, these are the same two games that I have been playing every weekend for weeks now, and no, I will not apologise for that.

I'm already nervously eyeing all the titles I'll want to pick up in the next seven days, so I'll be trying to enjoy having some money while I can. That said, there's a Black Friday deal on Star Wars Outlaws that's looking particularly tempting...

Ollie Reynolds, Staff Writer

I'd like to give Outlaws + Handful of Missions: Remaster a shot this weekend if I get chance – it looks so cool! Other than that, a quick dive into Metroid Prime Remastered before the fourth entry drops sounds like it might be on the cards. Have a good weekend, folks!

Gonçalo Lopes, Contributor

I forgot to mention that last weekend I went to the 10th edition of Lisboa Games Week. As one of the leading video game culture shows in Portugal, it is always a great place to meet old friends, make new ones and play the latest upcoming chart toppers. Nintendo had the biggest show floor ever, right at the main entrance, so it was impossible to miss all that Switch 2 red-tinted area. I was surprised to have play time with Final Fantasy VII Remake Intergrade and Elden Ring: Tarnished Edition, both running their demo builds quite smoothly. The main reason that made me not stay at home was hands-on with Metroid Prime 4: Beyond… and I was smiling the whole way. The latest entry in the series came out in 2007, I was an entirely different person back then. With the imminent release, I am clearing my schedule to ensure that it is all Samus Aran from next week onwards (and yes, my head is still back there, I got me a bad case of post-convention blues!).

My game of the week is Yakuza Kiwami 2. Will I be able to complete it before next week? Certainly not. Will I be redecorating the streets of Kamurochō with every street thug foolish enough to look me sideways until then? Put your money on the Dragon of Dojima, and you will never be poor again.

Kate Gray, Contributor

Not much time for gaming this weekend, as the HOLIDAY TIME has begun. I've got a Christmas party, a Christmas craft market, a house Christmas decoration plan, and a (not-Christmas) D&D session.

But I did just buy Outer Worlds 2 in the Steam Sale, like I said I would last week. So mayyyyyybe I can find the time in between all the Christmas...

Gavin Lane, Editor

I'm still playing and loving Shinobi, and the upcoming Animal Crossing update has got me surveying the state of my museum. Bugs, fossils, and fish-wise, I'm 100% complete, but my art gallery is perhaps 20% finished. So, I've started hitting Redd up on Harv's Island to see about changing that.

Elsewhere, I'm dipping into the Namco DLC for Atari 50, and the kids are intrigued by Katamari Damacy, so it might be time for a Reroll. Have a good one, folks.

Well, that's what we have planned for this weekend, but what about you? Let us know your picks in the following poll.

item.title: New Dead Rising Game May Be in Development, According to New Report
item.content:encoded:
• 0-20%: Unlikely - Lacks credible sources
  • 21-40%: Questionable - Some concerns remain
  • 41-60%: Plausible - Reasonable evidence
  • 61-80%: Probable - Strong evidence
  • 81-100%: Highly Likely - Multiple reliable sources

It's been nearly nine years since the release of Dead Rising 4, the latest new entry in CAPCOM's quirky zombie-themed action/adventure series.

At the time of its launch, the game was reviewed favorably by Wccftech's Jorge Jimenez, who gave it an 8 out of 10 rating. However, it failed to meet CAPCOM's sales projections, setting the series on a downward trend. Historic developer CAPCOM Vancouver was trying to make a different game afterward, a new IP which would have been set in an alternate version of New York, but that project was canceled in February 2018 and the studio suffered a cut of 20% of its manpower.

Meanwhile, the Vancouver team had also released a PvP puzzle game titled Puzzle Fighter for mobile devices. However, shortly after the aforementioned layoffs, the studio publicly vowed to refocus on its flagship franchise, Dead Rising.

Even that was not enough to save CAPCOM Vancouver from the parent company's axe, which fell on September 18, 2018, shutting down the 14-year-old studio for good with a total cost for the cancelled games estimated at around $40 million. A couple of years later, a rumor revealed that the Vancouver team had indeed started working on Dead Rising 5 before its closure. The limited information available suggests that the game was intended to take place in Santa Catarina, Mexico, between Dead Rising 2 and 3, featuring the protagonist of the former game, Chuck Greene.

With CAPCOM finally on a hot stream of game releases in the Resident Evil, Monster Hunter, and Devil May Cry franchises, the revival of this intellectual property didn't seem to be high on their priority. Still, the Deluxe Remaster was well received (despite some controversial changes to protagonist Frank West's face) and it also registered solid sales, according to the publisher.

That might have been the key to persuading CAPCOM to give the proverbial green light for a brand new game installment, which MP1st now reports is in development. The website's sources reckon a new title has been in the works since at least 2023 under the codename 'Rec'. This upcoming entry will once again feature Frank West and is reportedly going to be a sequel to the very first installment, suggesting that it might take place after DR1 but before DR2.

MP1st adds that the setting will be Hollywood, more specifically, a massive film studio lot where a crazed director forces Frank and other survivors to participate in various insane trials in the pursuit of filming the so-called perfect movie. The director will also send Psychopaths to hinder Frank, including the director's right-hand man, whom MP1st adds Frank had previously saved. This Psychopath is reportedly tasked with filming everything with a bomb strapped to his chest.

The time limit mechanics, a key feature of the Dead Rising franchise that was, however, absent in DR4, are supposedly returning with a vengeance. For instance, the movie director threatens to blow up the entire lot if Frank and the others don't comply with his orders. Of course, Frank's camera is also returning, and franchise fans will see other characters making appearances, including Isabela Keyes.

If the project started in 2023, we might be at least two to three years away from a release, given the average triple-A development timeframe, so best sit tight. Still, would you be happy if CAPCOM confirmed this rumor? Let us know in the comments.

item.title: Netflix’s Assassin’s Creed Series Setting Possibly Revealed
item.content:encoded:
The setting and time period of Netflix’s Assassin’s Creed series may have been revealed, according to a new report. Even more so, more information regarding the show’s development has emerged online.

Since 2007, the Assassin’s Creed series of games has been going rather strong, spanning eras of history with action-packed gameplay and gripping story. Earlier this year, Netflix announced that it’s working with Ubisoft to develop a live-action Assassin’s Creed series. Multiple ones are apparently in the works, as revealed in the blog from July, but the biggest one just cast actor Toby Wallace as co-lead. Now, more information on the show’s setting has reportedly been revealed, and it’s one that fans have been asking for for a long time.

Netflix’s Assassin’s Creed Series May Take Place in Ancient Rome, According to New Report

The report comes from an exclusive from Nexus Point News, which has previously leaked multiple game adaptations like God of War and Elden Ring. In the article, it mentions that sources have said what Netflix’s Assassin’s Creed’s setting will be: Ancient Rome. Specifically, the show is reportedly taking place between 54-68 AD during Emperor Nero’s reign. Both Nero and his mentor, Seneca, will be featured in the series. Filming is taking place in Italy, so it does line up there, if true.

Furthermore, the report says that Toby Wallace will be part of an ensemble cast, meaning there will be multiple leads. It’s important to note that Ubisoft and Netflix have not confirmed this news, so take it with a grain of salt. Still, Ancient Rome has been asked for by fans for a long time. However, if true, it would mean players would likely not get to play in that time period like they’d hoped to. This would also mean that the show would feature an original story, which is a bit of a risky move. Regardless, it’ll be interesting to see how the show shapes up.

Now, the Echo Show 15 is Amazon’s biggest effort to make a real home hub: This 15.6-inch Full HD display mounts on your wall like a digital bulletin board that actually earns its space, unlike the small 5-inch or 8-inch Echo Shows that work well on a nightstand.

Right now, you’re getting the newest model for $254 instead of $299, which is in line with Amazon’s Black Friday strategy of cutting its own hardware’s margins to almost nothing. This is the lowest price ever for a device that lets you control your smart home, stream entertainment, organize your family and make video calls all in one place.

Kitchen Command Center That Works

The 15.6-inch Full HD display changes how you use information all day because it has enough space to show more than one widget at a time. You can quickly check your family calendar, the weather, your shopping lists, and your smart home controls without having to swipe between screens or ask Alexa to read everything out loud. The customizable widget system lets you put the most important information for your family front and center, so you can find it quickly. This setup is great for kitchens where you need to check the schedule while cooking or for mudrooms where everyone needs to see the day’s schedule before they leave.

This is a real streaming device because it has built-in Fire TV functionality: It doesn’t just play content through voice commands with limited controls. You can use the included Fire TV remote to navigate Netflix, Prime Video, YouTube, Apple TV, and thousands of other apps in the same way you would on a regular TV. The picture quality is surprisingly good for casual viewing, like when you’re cooking dinner or doing the dishes.

When you can see and tap controls on a big screen instead of remembering voice commands or getting your phone out, controlling your smart home becomes a lot easier. You can see all of your connected devices on the dashboard at once. With just a few taps, you can turn off several lights, change the temperature, or check the feeds from your security cameras. You can see your front door, backyard, or kids’ rooms clearly on live camera feeds without having to squint at a small screen.

The auto-framing camera with 3.3x zoom and a wide field of view that keeps you centered in frame as you move around makes video calling a lot better. You can really cook and talk to family members at the same time without making them look at your ceiling or cutting yourself out of the picture. The noise-canceling technology gets rid of the sounds of blenders, running water, and other kitchen chaos that usually makes calls hard to hear. What’s more, the built-in shutter gives you physical privacy when you want to turn off the camera completely.

You get here a device that can stream, control your smart home, organize your family, and make high-quality video calls for only $254. That’s less than what you would pay for many standalone tablets and this price is only possible because Amazon cut its margin on Black Friday.

item.title: Surprise: The BrickBoy kit for the Lego Game Boy uses floating magnets instead of switches
item.content:encoded:
If you’re one of the nearly 3,500 Kickstarter backers paying to give your Lego Game Boy an actual screen and buttons, I have a question: did you expect those buttons to have physical switches underneath? That’s a real question.

Because the BrickBoy — not to be confused with Natalie the Nerd’s Build A Boy — is not currently going with physical clicks. Instead, it glues rare earth magnets inside Lego bricks, for what will hopefully be a magical experience… but isn’t one quite yet.

The magnets came as a surprise to me, because the BrickBoy Kickstarter, ending in three days, barely mentions magnets at all. Every one of the startup’s promo images shows domed switches underneath the buttons, the text of the Kickstarter does little to suggest otherwise, and we somehow missed that the company’s October 24th video narration briefly mentions that tiny magnets and “powerful 3D magnetometers” will control the action instead. So my question is genuine: did you back this expecting magnets, or switches?

To be fair, the magnets are a clever idea! Instead of having to hollow out much of the Lego Game Boy to fit a PCB, you only need to remove a few extra bricks here and there to fit a second magnetometer between the D-pad and face buttons. It’s easy to pop out the Start and Select keys (which are rubber tires) to fit a magnet inside; same with the A and B button posts. Here’s a glimpse at where those parts go:

When I press the A button, Mario jumps! When I press right on the D-pad, he runs. Some magnetic presses are being wirelessly detected. But I’m writing this story because — so far, with an early prototype — it doesn’t work very well. Like, I keep dying on the very first Goomba in Super Mario Bros, because I can’t stop running, or start jumping, reliably at all. Wireless multi-magnet sensing seems pretty ambitious from where I’m sitting right now!

It’s probably too early to judge that prototype. But it’s not too early to raise some eyebrows. Though Substance Labs published a video to YouTube that claimed you can build a “playable Lego Game Boy in 5 minutes”, it omitted the extra minutes it takes to wire up an entire magnetometer, remove extra Lego bricks to stuff it inside, and calibrate each and every magnet.

When I ask Substance Labs’ Thomas Bertani whether his backers know that magnets are at the controls — pointing out there’s nothing in his FAQ about it, and that a recent question about how the controls work went unanswered — Bertani says his team fully explained it in a new AMA video. But that video came out just yesterday, days ahead of the campaign’s conclusion, and only has 248 views at the time I type these words.

When I ask my colleague Andrew Liszewski, who’s covered the company twice, it’s a surprise to him too there are no switches. He says he assumed they’d be rubber domes. If we both missed it, did the product’s backers miss it as well?

Even if this is a surprise to you, it might be a welcome one! Whether you’re angry about any of this probably depends what you believe crowdfunding should be about. Are you funding an exact product that you want to exist, or are you funding a team to figure it out? Thomas Bertani tells me his team is figuring it out, building the most magical experience they can, and they’re ready to fall back to wired buttons if the magnets don’t work.

“I don’t think people care about it being magnets or wired buttons,” he tells me. “They do care about it working well and about the Lego experience being enjoyable,” he says, adding that the magnetometers actually make the product more expensive to produce.

Bertani says an early 800-backer survey suggested his customers care more about the building experience than the playing experience, that it “was clear they were Lego fans more than Game Boy fans,” and that many people were simply planning to put it on display.

I can imagine being one of those people: I would enjoy handing the Lego Game Boy to my friends, challenging them to figure out how it works, and then reveal the cleverly hidden magnets inside. If Substance Labs figures out how to make the magnets truly playable, it’d be the cherry on top for my investment.

But I believe I deserve to know what I’m betting on before I put money down, not after seeing lots of images suggesting I’ll be getting a physical button and assuming the device is built for play. Maybe that’s my mistake. Either way, Bertani tells me he’ll update all his backers this weekend, before the campaign ends, to be more transparent about how the device works.

Coincidentally, Natalie the Nerd just posted a new update on her Build a Boy project today, including a photo of the actual switches she’ll be using for the buttons. That Lego Game Boy may not be exceptionally playable either, mind. She writes: “It’s important for me to reinstate that at the end of the day it is Lego. I wouldn’t suggest this being an everyday carry item.”

Update, November 28th: Clarified that the BrickBoy team did previously mention magnetometers briefly in the Kickstarter video; restructured the story to make it clearer that my initial question is a genuine one.

item.title: Apple Cuts Watch SE 3 Price Beyond Original Plan, Garmin and Samsung Went So Low Apple Had to React
item.content:encoded:
This is the first year that Apple has put all of its Watch models on sale at the same time on Black Friday: This includes the rugged Watch Ultra model for extreme sports, the standard Series models, and the SE models that are focused on value. This all-encompassing sale strategy gives people access to Apple’s wearable ecosystem in ways that have never been possible before, since Apple usually keeps prices high except for short promotional periods (and mainly on Amazon).

Since this morning, the price of the Apple Watch SE 3 with 44mm GPS (and sport band) on Amazon dropped from $279 to $229. This is the lowest price ever with an 18% discount that makes it a good choice against affordable Samsung and Garmin watches at similar prices. Amazon went above and beyond the usual Black Friday discounts, making the Apple Watch SE 3 the best-selling smartwatch on the main Black Friday day.

See at Amazon

Always-On Display

The always-on Retina display is the SE 3’s biggest improvement over the SE 2: It gets rid of the need to raise your wrist which made previous models feel half-functional when you just wanted to check the time. It also means that you can check notifications during meetings without the obvious wrist flick that says you’re looking at your watch, or keep track of your workout metrics without waking up the screen by making big movements.

The temperature sensing lets you look back at ovulation estimates by taking nightly wrist temperature readings that show patterns that point to fertile windows. This makes natural family planning tools or fertility awareness that dedicated ovulation trackers offer at similar prices. The Vitals app combines temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and sleep data into unified health dashboards that show patterns that individual metrics don’t show. Daily sleep scores measure the quality of your sleep by looking at how long you sleep, how consistently you sleep, and how your body works.

The new battery lasts 18 hours on a single charge and has an always-on display so you can use it all day, from waking up to going to sleep, without having to charge it in the middle of the day, which makes sleep tracking impossible. Fast charging gives you 8 hours of battery life in just 15 minutes, so you can quickly charge it up while you shower or get ready in the morning. The battery lasts twice as long as the SE 2’s and the new charging architecture makes it charge twice as fast.

The Apple Intelligence-powered Workout Buddy looks at your past workouts to give you personalized coaching, changing goals, and real-time support that keeps you motivated during tough sessions. The feature learns how well you usually do and changes its suggestions based on that, so you don’t get the unrealistic goals that generic fitness apps give you without knowing what you can really do.

The crash and fall detection features use data from the accelerometer and gyroscope to look for serious impacts or dangerous falls. If you don’t respond after an incident, they will automatically call emergency services. The safety features are especially useful for people who do things alone, like running on remote trails, biking on busy streets, or older people who are more likely to fall.

The record-low Black Friday pricing at $229 makes Apple’s latest Watch SE 3 model cost similarly to Samsung and Garmin alternatives but they offer better ecosystem integration, safety features and seamless iPhone connectivity that Android watches cannot match. The combination of always-on display, temperature sensing, 18-hour battery and Apple Intelligence features at 18% below retail creates exceptional value.

item.title: Microsoft Goes Zero-Profit on Surface Laptop (1TB SSD, X Elite, 15″), Now $700 Off in Black Friday’s Final Hours
item.content:encoded:
For the last few hours of Black Friday, Microsoft has decided to go all out by cutting prices even more on its Surface laptop line (the Surface Pro tablets are getting the same treatment on Amazon). There is only one model that is 41% off the original price, and it is this powerful 15-inch Surface Laptop with a Snapdragon X Elite processor, 16GB of RAM, and a huge 1TB SSD. Instead of the usual $1,699, this Copilot+ PC costs $999 ($700 off) which puts it in the premium range without the high price tag. This isn’t just another laptop deal: it’s Microsoft’s first big step into AI-enhanced computing for regular people and the hardware that comes with it actually lives up to those promises.

See at Amazon

Snapdragon Power Lasts All Day

This Surface laptop has a Snapdragon X Elite processor, which is a big change from Intel or AMD chips. Microsoft says that it works better than the MacBook Air M3. Benchmarks show that it does, but the 12-core architecture makes it surprisingly easy to do more than one thing at once. When you have a lot of browser tabs open, music streaming, and documents open at the same time, you’ll notice this the most. The built-in NPU (Neural Processing Unit) is what really makes it better because it does AI tasks locally instead of sending data to cloud servers: This means that features like real-time translation and image processing will work faster, and your data will be safer because it stays on your device. And the good news is that you don’t need to be connected to the internet all the time to use the AI features that come with Copilot+.

It can last up to 20 hours on a single charge which is longer than most Windows laptops in this category. You can really get through a whole day of meetings, presentations, and editing documents without having to look for outlets. The Snapdragon architecture makes it more efficient because it uses less power than older x86 processors.

The 15-inch touchscreen display uses HDR technology to make the brightness levels high enough to work outside. The ultra-thin bezels make the most of the screen space without making the laptop bigger, and the colors are bright without being too bright. When using Windows 11’s touch-optimized interface, the touch functionality responds right away, which is more important than you might think.

Windows Studio Effects changes video calls by changing the lighting in real time, blocking out background noise, and blurring the mess behind you. These features run on the NPU instead of your main processor, so they don’t slow down calls. The live translation feature works in 44 languages and makes subtitles for video calls and streaming content in real time. It’s processing everything on your own computer so there won’t be any lag and you won’t have to worry about sending your conversations through outside servers.

Right now, you get specs that would normally cost well into four figures for $999: Just the 16GB of RAM and 1TB of storage are worth a lot, and that’s before you even think about the display quality and battery life. This setup gets rid of the usual trade-offs: you don’t have to choose between storage space and budget, and you don’t have to give up RAM to get good battery life. Microsoft has called this their flagship AI laptop, and the Black Friday sale makes it competitive with mid-range laptops that can’t match its features.
